I think the "super-net" idea used here could cause problems for deployments adding DCN to existing Octavia deployments. If there are existing amphora that are using an IP outside of the /18 "sub-subnet" this patch sets up for the existing Octaiva deployment, they would be impacted by the routing changes and become unavailable. This can occur from either a large number of load balancers being deployed, or from the incremental IP assignment neutron uses (i.e. natural amphora churn).
We should be able to use another address space to carve up for the DCN site management networks, say 10.0.0.0/8, which would allow this playbook to not disturb the existing Octavia deployment and remove the need to restart Octavia services and add host routes to the o-hm0 interface. It would also make it easier for us to identify the DCN an amp/load balancer was deployed in.
Maybe consider that approach?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I also agree it makes sense to test OpenStack in FIPS-compatible environment by default. It should cover our needs.
I have added some wording nits.  All-in-all I support this.

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Yes, in essence, at any given point in time, the slow-moving USA NIST approval process will mean that there are some improvements (security-related or otherwise) which aren't available in FIPS compliant deployments. This doesn't mean that we shouldn't attempt to make it possible for operators to deploy on such a platform (any platform will have some shortcomings after all), just that we shouldn't only test in FIPS mode and that we shouldn't expect OpenDev sysadmins to be able to assist with troubleshooting such problems in jobs running under "FIPS mode" as they're not equipped with the necessary familiarity and tools to do so (e.g., they may use SSH keys which are not covered by relevant NIST publications).
> 
> My biggest concern with putting too much focus on FIPS standards is that they're necessarily Americentric, yet OpenStack is developed and used globally. Will we invest similar amounts of effort in GOST (ГОСТ) compliance? Or the PRC's SM9?

Echoing your point here, the comments here indicate reasons that we shouldn't only support and test in FIPS compliant environments.

From the point of view of selecting libraries, we would need to either use libraries that support both FIPS and non-FIPS (ed25519) or make it possible to select a FIPS compliant library (through configuration or otherwise).
 
Doing work to support FIPS compliant deployments does not preclude doing work to achieve other compliance standards.  The more compliance standards we support, the more widely deployable OpenStack will be.  That said, much of the work that is done to support FIPS will likely help reach other compliance targets too.

Should community goals only target concerns that are global in scope?

I think there's some agreement we should test for both FIPS and non-FIPS usage. Have we come up with some ideas on how this can be done and the paramiko concerns? 

@fickler have your concerns been addressed or do you have any suggestions for resolution?
Seeing that I cannot login with my ed25519 ssh key into CI instances in fips mode, I claim that fips compliance is not a valid target for openstack.
Some wording/typo comments in-line.  I think this continues to head in the right direction.

Well this proposal is talking only about FIPS 140-3 afaict from the link provided, maybe the wording should become more explicit in that regard. Also I have no idea what's actually inside that document, I can only speak from my experience with actual CI nodes that were deployed. And from that it would seem like at least 40% of the current infra-roots would either have to change their SSH keys to some potentially less secure option or would not be able to debug any FIPS related CI issues properly.

In addition, there is also a general concern that using FIPS-certified libraries may be less secure, because there is a certain incentive to not publish security issues and fixes[0]. This would in particular make the move away from paramiko questionable IMO.

[0] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIPS_140#Criticism

I think testing both fips and non-fips means that each project will need to add at least one CI job that tests when fips is enabled.  This job should test enough of the functionality for the project to be confident in the results.  The remaining jobs will continue to test in non-fips environments.

We're still looking into how to best move forward with a paramiko replacement, but we have found that a relatively small patch of paramiko will allow us to be fips-compatible if not fips compliant. [1]

When we do find a replacement, if we can't find something that works for FIPS and non-FIPS, we'll be sure to allow for both cases depending on config.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/822560

goals/proposed/fips.rst.message:
It might be a good idea to describe the end goal for ongoing CI/testing here as well. Ideally (imo at least) we'd avoid running fips and non fips duplicated jobs for everything. And reasonable functional testing is probably sufficient for coverage?

This way it is clear for projects when they've completed work to be reasonably compliant (enable jobs foo and bar, or swap existing jobs for existing jobs + fips, etc).

Up to now, I've consulted with each team and asked them to select the best set of tests to ensure coverage.  The result has been a mix of unit/functional/tempest tests.

I do like the goal though of trying to replace existing jobs with FIPS jobs, rather than having duplicate jobs.  If it works under FIPS, then it should work without FIPS.  And if we have a job that is run without FIPS enabled, then there's a good known reason.

An additional note here.  

After looking at how I hacked paramiko to work, its clear that the main issue is a call to md() when generating fingerprints, which are then written to log files.
No secret data is involved here - so this is a perfectly acceptable use of md5() under fips.

There are two ways to resolve this in paramiko - either use the usedforsecurity parameter as in here: https://github.com/vakwetu/paramiko/commit/b4beb535d7293447f25afd12051dbc45bb1e6ddc or allow the use of a different algorithm as in here: https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/pull/1103

Paramiko also uses md5() in generating a key from a password while reading an encrypted PEM file that is not in the newer OpenSSH format.  We can get around that by simply making sure that relavant encrypted key files are generated by OpenSSH.

That brings up a salient point though - which is that paramiko implements a lot of its own crypto - which - without significant investment - will not be FIPS certified.

So, while we will be able to reach FIPS compatibility relatively easily with paramiko, we will need to replace paramiko across openstack for FIPS compliance, just as we would for other non-FIPS certified crypto libraries.
I'm surprised Sphinx is a runtime requirement. Where did this come up? Are people actually trying to build documentation on FIPS-compatible systems?

sphinx came up in the tripleo CI jobs, because there is at least one job where the required packages are built through dlrn and containers are created.  We worked around this by specifying that these jobs would run on a non-fips enabled system.

There is a fix for this in sphinx, but its in a version much later than whats in requirements.
you mean Tempest tests? there is no refstack tests and it run the tempest tests itself

I'm having a hard time understanding how this case is possible. If we have:

  version = 1
  model_api = 1
  MODEL_API = 1

Then this case would never be hit? I think the intent may have been to dedent this case so that it is an elif to the version > self.model_api check?

If our version is 2 and we join a cluster where everyone else is 1, then we have
version=1, model_api=1, MODEL_API=2.

Then when the last old component is upgraded, we have:
version=2, model_api=1, MODEL_API=2.

The check on line 348 is True, 349 is False, 356 is True.

This catches the exact moment the cluster upgrades.  At the bottom of this we update model_api to be version and this won't hit the next time through.
Thank you for the explanation. I guess we only want to log the point when all components are up to date and don't need to log that they are currently up to date each time through.

Clay is right, seems we already have a way of logging headers in proxy logging.

Here is a log line by default from my SAIO:

  Jan 27 02:46:39 saio1 proxy-server[15151]: 127.0.0.1 127.0.0.1 27/Jan/2022/02/46/39 GET /v1/AUTH_test/ec/o HTTP/1.0 206 - curl/7.58.0 AUTH_tk02a16e525... - 99 - tx9f01d25c5aa94ad5b30f3-0061f2078f - 0.0246 - - 1643251599.145984888 1643251599.170571089 1

Then if we add to the proxy-logging section of the configuration:

  [filter:proxy-logging]
  use = egg:swift#proxy_logging
  access_log_headers = true
  access_log_headers_only = Range

Then we get:

  Jan 27 02:49:51 saio1 proxy-server[15444]: 127.0.0.1 127.0.0.1 27/Jan/2022/02/49/51 GET /v1/AUTH_test/ec/o HTTP/1.0 206 - curl/7.58.0 AUTH_tk02a16e525... - 99 - txbff7b6ff6ee2496f825e8-0061f2084f Range:%20bytes%3D0-98 0.0684 - - 1643251791.292458057 1643251791.360898018 1

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message: in time we'll probably want to add some guidance as to how to choose an appropriate number, but we may need some experience before we can write that

My gut says something in the [0, 0.1] range is probably about right -- or at least, not so wrong as to cause things to fall over. The main things informing tuning seem to be:

* How long is the recheck interval? Longer interval should mean you can turn down the skip_pct, since you're more likely to catch it at some point in the interval.
* What's your client load? Too high and you may still overwhelm your container servers; too low and you'll never actually refresh cache.
* What client load can your container servers keep up with? There must be some point where it's acceptable to have things fall out of cache.

I got your point and we need to clarify on how to proceed in this case.

Current PTP configuration is loosely associated with the hosts: when 'clock_synchronization' is set to 'ptp', that host is configured with the global parameters. On the other hand, the new data model makes the association between a PTP instance and a particular host to be explicit.

In order to mimic the legacy behavior, then I should create as many instances as the number of [current? configured?] hosts in the system. Or, the host field could be Null in this case, meaning the instance apply to all hosts.
The legacy parameters need to be associated with every host that has clock_synchronization=ptp rather than controller-0.

We are going to have to include a phc2sys global parameter for uds_address, as this will be required to associate the legacy phc2sys instance with the legacy ptp4l instance. I can provide additional details to clarify.
Also, do we already know all of such parameters that should be automatically set during this upgrade step?

"domainNumber should be configured as a global parameter for BOTH default ptp4l and default phc2sys, value should be the same for both"

Wherever it comes from (found or not in service-parameter table), it will be on set on both instances, right? Is it the only already supported that should be duplicated due to that split of config files?

"Putting in another way: create default ptp4l AND phc2sys instances if the following in the current patchset (#9) is true:
if len(ptp_entries) > 0 or len(host_entries) > 0"

Correct

domainNumber should be configured as a global parameter for BOTH default ptp4l and default phc2sys, value should be the same for both

uds_address just needs to be applied to phc2sys

"default ptp4l and phc2sys services should be created if there are existing ptp4l and phc2sys configurations. There may not be service_parameter entries to be migrated, but we need to create the instances if ptp is configured."

Putting in another way: create default ptp4l AND phc2sys instances if the following in the current patchset (#9) is true:
if len(ptp_entries) > 0 or len(host_entries) > 0:

"In multi-instance, they use separate config files so we need two parameters to map phc2sys to ptp4l
domainNumber <value present in service_parameter OR 24 if none>
uds_address /var/run/ptp4l-default <- this name should be whatever you decide to name the default ptp4l instance."

Just to confirm that while uds_address is clear to be created as default phy2sys's instance, domainNumber is to be created as default ptp4l's instance since it is originally a "global" parameter in service-parameter.

UPDATE: domain should be 0 if not found in service_paramter
domainNumber <value present in service_parameter OR 0 if none>

So this would be a PTP parameter to be always included in 'ptp_parameters' table for phc2sys, together with the ones eventually found and added in the specific logic below, is that correct?

Does it mean that default instances for ptp4l and phc2sys services will be *always* created, regardless there are/aren't service_parameter entries to be migrated (thus differently from this current implementation)?

"Does it mean that default instances for ptp4l and phc2sys services will be *always* created, regardless there are/aren't service_parameter entries to be migrated?"

default ptp4l and phc2sys services should be created if there are existing ptp4l and phc2sys configurations. There may not be service_parameter entries to be migrated, but we need to create the instances if ptp is configured.

For this design there are two parameters that must always be included for phc2sys. In the single instance config, ptp4l and phc2sys shared a config file, so there was no need to map them together. In multi-instance, they use separate config files so we need two parameters to map phc2sys to ptp4l
domainNumber <value present in service_parameter OR 24 if none>
uds_address /var/run/ptp4l-default <- this name should be whatever you decide to name the default ptp4l instance.

tools/zk-analyze.py.message: I think we probably do want both.
What's the primary goal of the analysis? Is it 'how much data is in zk' or 'how much data is in the model'? In case of the first we probably don't want to decompress here. Maybe we even want both?

The decompression needs to be done here on the node data and not on the concatenated byte string below.

            zk_size = 0
            for shard in shards:
                with open(os.path.join(fullpath, shard, 'ZKDATA'), 'rb') as f:
                    compressed_data = f.read()
                    data += zlib.decompress(compressed_data)
                    zk_size = len(compressed_data)
            return Data(path, data, zk_size=zk_size)

There is a small bug in the above snipped related to the zk_size. This should be:

            zk_size = 0
            for shard in shards:
                with open(os.path.join(fullpath, shard, 'ZKDATA'), 'rb') as f:
                    compressed_data = f.read()
                    data += zlib.decompress(compressed_data)
                    zk_size += len(compressed_data)
            return Data(path, data, zk_size=zk_size)
Shouldn't we use the zk size for the attribute size if the `use_zk_size` flag is set? Same question for the other summary items below that also have 'attributes'.

Actually, no, it's not reflected in the tree size because this is treating offloaded attributes as part of the object.

Because offloaded attributes may or may not be offloaded (they are only offloaded if they reach a certain size), this treats them all as if they were part of the object.  For example, a "Job" may have its "vars" attribute inline in the Job JSON, or it may be offloaded to a different znode.  For the purpose of us finding out whether "vars" is really big, we don't care whether it's offloaded or not.  If we did this naively, we wight use the "depth" option which would end up excluding Job vars if they are large and offloaded but including them if they were small and inline, and that would be weird.

And to put this another way, since the vars are not included in the tree_size, we should continue to add them to the size.

I think we should not add the size of the children to the size of the parent as this is already reflected in the tree size. But then we need to include the attribute sizes in the tree_size/zk_tree_size properties.
We need to forward the `zk` flag here.

Any concerns around races when either dumping from zk or reading it directly from zk here? Looks like we iterate over shards and just mark them as failed if they don't exist which is probably good enough for most analysis.
It might be that the dump script is a little faster than the analyzer, but at least I did not encounter any issues when dumping our production ZK during peak hours.
I think if we are using the ZK size option we should also limit matches by the ZK size.
Sorry to -1 this once more, but now that the data in ZK is compressed we need to open this file 'rb'.
See comment on the dump script. I think this one will be a bit more clear if the other command is updated. But maybe consider noting this is in lieu of talking to Zk directly?

could we try to decompress so that the data can be read directly?
Any reason to not use os.path.join here and below with the recursive getTree call arg?
That would work, but given the tight control of input values it's not necessary.
We need to forward the decompress flag here.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Since it's a bug - we're missing a reno.
Docs also need to be updated (Neutron guide - ML2/OVN section).

Wait a moment, what happened with going with the same approach as we have in ML2/OVS?

We're setting dnsmasq_dns_servers = {{ neutron_dnsmasq_dns_servers }} in dhcp-agent.ini - so why not just define a variable neutron_dns_servers, update neutron_dnsmasq_dns_servers to point to the new variable - and use a common default for both ML2/OVS and ML2/OVN?
I think I agree with frickler more. It is best users tinkering with networking actually understand what they are doing.

I considered that, but the use is really quite different. neutron_dnsmasq_dns_servers is what the Neutron DHCP-Agent uses as forwarders while responding to instances from its own addresses, so tenants never see those addresses.

In contrast, neutron_ovn_dns_servers are the addresses that OVN tells the instances to use as DNS servers via the DHCP response.

If you tell me: "Bah, nobody cares about those details, DNS is DNS", you might be able to convince me, but I'd really prefer to keep the patch like it is now.

ansible/roles/neutron/defaults/main.yml.message: what's that default? For neutron_dnsmasq_dns_servers we have "1.1.1.1,8.8.8.8,8.8.4.4" - shouldn't we have the same defaults?

Well then either we default to empty variable and | length > 0 in the template, or we start with a sensible default (similar to ML2/OVS one) with a proper reno and docs entry (for those that will break). Which one is it?

I took the default from the neutron docs https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-dns-res.html , I wasn't aware that kolla has other defaults, I will adapt those instead. Or should we rather use the same default as neutron? I'm not sure that defaulting to Cloudflare and Google is a very reasonable choice.
Let's do the same what we have for ML2/OVS - defaulting to non working DNS (203.0.113.8 is Test-Net-3 for documentation purposes) probably won't help either ;-)
It's broken in some cases, in others maybe the correct internal DNS config is used already and this change would break them.
Well the reason to set this by default is that the old default is broken, see the linked bug. I'd prefer to have a working deployment by default instead of just documenting how to make it work.

Let's go with not adding this variable at all and just documenting the OVN's behaviour properly (so that operators get to know this detail and how to control it), i.e., show that config override can be used here (it's what we have it for).

There is a difference between dns_servers for OVN and dnsmasq_dns_servers for OVS. The former gets passed to instances via DHCP options, whereas the latter is used by the DHCP agent to proxy DNS requests.

Should we even set a default here? Or just document that you may want to set the option?

ansible/roles/neutron/templates/ml2_conf.message: this will not work; first of all, it will not be triggered as the variable is always defined; secondly, "omit" only works as ansible module argument - outside of that scope the magic string is not interpreted and would confuse neutron

Let's use "if", it will be safer (I hope).

"default" will work like you said if and only if you set its second argument to "true" (then it will consider falsey values as undefined and change them to the default).

Hmm, o.k., so should I wrap this in another "if" block instead? Or are you fine with always setting this variable?

Also, according to ansible docs, "default(omit)" should also work if the variable is defined but empty. But I agree that this is the wrong scope here.

releasenotes/notes/neutron_ovn_dns_serve.message: let's also add an "upgrade" section as this changes the behaviour; for some folks the previous default could be worky (i.e., they did not have loopback in resolv.conf)
Good point, done, also added the "default(omit)" filter to allow deployers to actually keep the old default.

docker/ironic/ironic-pxe/extend_start.sh.message: This was previously EFI/centos. Is it ok to change?

For ironic doc[1], it use distros provided grub efi so it need to create grub.cfg dir as distros. Kolla generates grub efi itself now, but maybe we should use distros' grub efi instead like ironic doc. Anyway, changing grub.cfg dir will also need to Synchronous change kolla-ansible[2] , if we want to change it I prefer a separate patch for it.

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html#uefi-pxe-grub-setup
[2]: 
https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/0a1ccc2612240ff15c255eeafc67f56835278adf/ansible/roles/ironic/templates/ironic-pxe.json.j2#L1

I need to double check this. The ironic doc tells it will need this dir.
https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html#pxe-multi-architecture-setup
It might be cleaner to add this to a new prepare_grub function.
We should consider mixed arch environments too. Do these files exist in an AARCH64 install? If so, keeping them would allow us to PXE boot x86 machines.
Then can we create a universal image able to boot any supported arch? It should make it nicer to handle multiarch while being simpler at the same time. :-)

No, we can't. Different arch has different efi executable format[1]. Syslinux only support x86 legacy BIOS boot mode. And for UEFI grub boot mode, current ironic supports multiarch bare metal provisioning via options "xxx_by_arch"[2] if we use neutron dhcp provider, e.g.:

pxe_bootfile_name_by_arch=aarch64:grubaa64.efi,ppc64:bootppc64
pxe_config_template_by_arch=aarch64:pxe_grubaa64_config.template,ppc64:pxe_ppc64_config.template
 

[1]: see --format option, https://www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/1-grub2-mkimage/
[2]: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html#pxe-multi-architecture-setup
You are right, we should consider mixed arch bare metal node deployment. these files exist in AArch64 install. We should keep these files.
Should we copy both sets of files on both arches? That would in theory allow x86 to boot aarch64 and vice versa

But, usually, in container it can only install one arch binary at a time. Supporting multi-arch UEFI booting might need to copy other arch grub bins manually. See https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html#pxe-multi-architecture-setup

oslo_cache/_opts.py.message: I'm wondering if we want to mention that enable_retry_client must be true for these to have any effect. It's not necessarily clear that retry client relates to hashclient.

No, enable_retry_client don't need to be true to use hashclient_retry_attempts [1]... pymemcache come with 2 retry mechanisms. the first one is enable_retry_client which is an external wrapper that can wrap any memcached client [2], the second one is internal to the pymemcache's hashclient (a client) [3], so even if the wrapper is not activated the internal retrying feature of this client (used by dogpile.cache to communicate with pymemcache) can be used [4].

neutron/conf/policies/qos.py.message:
I think it was agreed long time ago when that API was introduced that it should be "ADMIN ONLY" (then we didn't had scopes at all) because it is displaying things like backend drivers which are used in the cloud, so some infra related things.
I think that now it is safe to show it to system users but I don't think it should be available for project users - they shouldn't need it at all.
Should PROJECT_ADMIN be able to get this info as well? Seems a candidate for an exception (as mentioned in the commit message) - and actually I see it as an exception in the test

we can just make it role:admin and scope as both system and project. like doing in nova https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/819390/7/nova/policies/aggregates.py

also I think you should remove the 'system_scope:all' hardcoded string from SYSTEM_READER ?https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/conf/policies/base.py#L55

That was/is the things which made our policy with new defaults with enforce_scope=False (default) not working on defaults vs scope.

That is the goal here to remove the current hardcoded 'system_scope:all' string from check_str. I am in progress for doing it for nova (changing the usage first, and then I will update the base class ). The idea here is that when we enforce scope by default and users want more time to switch to new policy/scope, they can disable the scope and their admin token (project one) can keep working. If we have 'system_scope:all' string in system check_str then it will not be possible (this is the problem we are solving in new direction.). In this approach, there was a disadvantage for making SYSTEM_READER that way (remove 'system_scope:all' from SYSTEM_READER rule), if we do that then if scope is disabled then project reader can also access those system level APIs. To solve that we agreed not to use the SYSTEM_READER or SYSTEM_MEMBER in this phase1 and do it in phase3[1]. We need to convert all the SYSTEM_READER to SYSTEM_ADMIN(with no 'system_scope:all' string in check_str) so that we do not allow project reader to able to access the system level API.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#phase-3

I'm not sure I understand first part of Your comment. Why we should make it"role:admin" only? It should be available for admin users and SYSTEM_READER/MEMBER too.
Also it has already scope_types both project and system.

Regarding second part of comment I can change it but it seems that it should be changed across all projects as everywhere it is defined in same way. Is that correct?

neutron/conf/policies/service_type.py.message:

SYSTEM_OR_PROJECT_READER check string also checks project_id of the resource and service_provider don't have it. That's why we can't use that constant here and need to use custom check string to check only role.

IIUC the question is about "why not PROJECT_READER or SYSTEM_READER?", right?
If that's the question, the answer is, because PROJECT reader has got "project_id:%(project_id)s" in the check string and service_provider resource don't have project attribute. That would cause error while enforcing this policy so because of that there is only "role:reader" in the check string here.

tox.ini.message:
i'd rather add here an extra line:

-r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt

instead of adding eventlet in doc/requirements.txt. Since what happens here is that due to 'usedevelop=True' the 'develop-inst' tox phase installs os-ken, but it does it without any constraints. However, if os-ken's requirements are added to deps, then they are all installed in 'installdeps' phase with the above constraints, and during 'develop-inst' they won't be reinstalled. This would be more future-proof. With the current solution, whenever a new incompatible package is released we need to add its restriction to doc/requirements.txt.
Thanks for the explanation Elod! This would work well indeed for os-ken or similar projetcs where requirements.txt list is short

I'm not sure I agree this is the place to do this.  

The point of this reset of the BLS entries was to make the regular path of "grub-mkconfig" in the bootloader "just work" as it does on ... every other distro.  And indeed we can remove this when https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2032680 is available too.  So I'm not sure why we need to do this here, it just seems to confuse the matter of where the kernel options are being set.

Bug #1958230 is for an overcloud-full partition image, which doesn't actually use the bootloader element, so grub2-mkconfig is not actually called to auto-fix it.

I'd frame this as a "fix the base image" rather than a "set kernel options" thing.

I'm not really following ... how has the overcloud-full job been setting the right root= option for all other distros if it's not using the bootloader?  I'm worried that we'll get the grub fix in and delete this, and then break the overcloud-full job again.
I guess the only other place to do this for the bug in question is in the grub2 element :/

Just a quick confirmation: the modified patch[1] works as expected, I could get my OC node provisioned.
The image had the right entry, as I could confirm before actually using it[2]

[1] https://paste.opendev.org/show/812333/
[2] https://paste.opendev.org/show/812332/

PS: I'm using the oooci-image-build role from tripleo-ci, and have some more patches in the loop:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/812335/

Note about the kernel line: with this patch, I don't have the console output anymore.
So while it seems to match "until the first space", it seems to remove the console options, leading to a black screen, masking everything happening after the grub prompt. This is a regression from previous state. I'll try to know more by inspecting the actual content.

OK - after some more investigations:
- we shouldn't replace but generate the "options" line imho
- doing so, we'd ensure we get a consistent and valid entry, not depending on how/where we generate the image.

So, instead of that "simple" sed, we should probably do something more invasive, such as:
sed -i 's|options .*|options root=LABEL=${DIB_ROOT_LABEL} ro console=${SERIAL_CONSOLE} no_timer_check net.ifnames=0 crashkernel=1G-4G:192M,4G-64G:256M,64G-:512M|'

Not sure about the $SERIAL_CONSOLE, it might be $DIB_BOOTLOADER_SERIAL_CONSOLE - to be confirmed.

Doing so, we'll end up with a 100% known "options" line, with the correct values we may expect.

@Steve: any thoughts?
This can hopefully be abandoned in favor of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/826205

here's the content of the loader/entries:
title CentOS Stream (5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64) 9
version 5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64
linux /boot/vmlinuz-5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64
initrd /boot/initramfs-5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64.img
options root=/dev/mapper/fedora_fedora-root ro rd.lvm.lv=fedora_fedora/root rhgb quiet
grub_users $grub_users
grub_arg --unrestricted
grub_class centos

That's a bit weird. As if it took the lvm things from the host that actually built the image... ?!
removing vote - I'm pretty sure it has something to do with my env.

I've made the switch to bootloader here:
  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/826205

This resulted in the following BLS entry with a local build:

  # cat 5c772024bd164618885e10e8154518ae-5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64.conf 
  title CentOS Stream (5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64) 9
  version 5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64
  linux /boot/vmlinuz-5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64
  initrd /boot/initramfs-5.14.0-44.el9.x86_64.img
  options root=LABEL=img-rootfs ro console=ttyS0,115200n8 no_timer_check  crashkernel=auto console=tty0 console=ttyS0,115200 no_timer_check nofb nomodeset gfxpayload=text
  grub_users $grub_users
  grub_arg --unrestricted
  grub_class centos

the bootloader is where we properly set up the kernel arguments, but this element is only used by overcloud-hardened-uefi-full. The overcloud-full image only uses the grub2 element, which is very simple and quite different to bootloader.

I'm going to look into moving overcloud-full to use the bootloader element. Other than fixing this specific issue, it will reduce our support matrix now that overcloud-full is approaching deprecation.

Note: the SERIAL_CONSOLE has to be set - apparently it's set in another file, included far, far later:
diskimage_builder/elements/bootloader/finalise.d/50-bootloader

So I'm wondering if we're not mixing things - why are we setting up these files now instead of "later", when we actually hit the bootloader part ?

ah, might indeed be better. Lemme first test my current build, this will allow me to see if the logic is correct, then I'll later test your other patch and add a comment there.

Thanks for the hard work!
